nodes.name: One Nation
nodes.abt: One Nation is a 501c4 social welfare organization operated by Karl Rove and his associates. Because they're tax exempt, they do not have to disclose their donors to the FEC. According to a leaked copy of their tax filings, the group spent about $40M in a largely successful push to protect the GOP’s majority in the Senate, with over half of the $40M being provided by four anonymous donors.

nodes.name: Miriam Adelson
nodes.abt: Miriam Adelson (nee Ochsorn) is an Israeli doctor who specializes in treating addiction. She married Sheldon Adelson in 1991. In addition to funding conservative candidates, Miriam and Sheldon are major donors to Taglit-Birthright Israel. Like Sheldon, Miriam also gave $17.5M dollars to the Senate Leadership Fund.

nodes.name: Sheldon Adelson
nodes.abt: Sheldon Adelson is a business magnate whose primary investments are hotels and casinos. He is the 19th richest person in the world and the largest individual donor from any party during the 2012 and 2016 election cycles. He gave $17.5M dollars to the Senate Leadership Fund.

nodes.name: Paul Singer
nodes.abt: Paul Singer is the founder of Elliott Management Corporation--a hedge fund which specializes in distressed debt acquisitions. Singer serves on the board of the Republican Jewish Coalition and has donated over $10M to conservative groups and candidates who support LGBT equality. Paul Singer gave $6M to the Senate Leadership Fund.

nodes.name: Petrodome Energy
nodes.abt: Petrodome Energy is a private oil and gas producer run by Ed Borsarge--a mathematician whose specialties include finance, medicine and energy. He appears wearing a beret in every photo I've found of him online. Petrodome Energy gave $4M to the Senate Leadership Fund.

nodes.name: Stephen Schwarzman
nodes.abt: Stephen Schwarzman is the CEO of The Blackstone Group, a global private equity firm. He made headlines in 2017 for his 70th birthday party which costed $7M dollars. The party included a 12 minute fireworks show, roaming camels and a 'Happy Birthday' performance from Gwen Stefani. He gave $3.1m to the Senate Leadership Fund.

nodes.name: Warren Stephens
nodes.abt: Warren Stephens is the chairman, president and CEO of Stephens Inc, a privately held investment bank. He was an active donor in the 'Stop Trump' movement during the republican primaries. He gave $3M to the Senate Leadership Fund.

nodes.name: Robert McNair
nodes.abt: Robert "Bob" McNair is a businessman best known for his ownership of the Houston Texans. He ignited controversy during the fall 2017 anthem-kneeling protests by comparing the player protests to 'inmates running the prison.' He apologized, and then retracted his apology in April 2018. He gave $2.5M to the Senate Leadership Fund.

nodes.name: American Crossroads
nodes.abt: American Crossroads is a conservative super PAC that aims to focus its activities on what it sees as 'America’s commitment to individual liberty, limited government, free enterprise and a strong national defense.' The organization was founded in 2010 by a group of Republican political operatives led by Karl Rove. They gave $2.5M to the Senate Leadership Fund.

nodes.name: Kenneth Griffin
nodes.abt: Kenneth Griffin is the CEO of the global investment firm, Citadel. During his sophomore year at Harvard (1987), he installed a satellite link to his dorm room in order to access real-time stock market data. He is an active art buyer, having paid millions for notable works of art by Paul Cezanne, Jackson Pollock and Jasper Johns. He gave $2.1m to the Senate Leadership Fund.

nodes.name: Senate Leadership Fund
nodes.abt: This conservative superPAC spent a total of $86 million dollars on 2016 senate elections, including $17M in NV, $15M in PA, $14M in NC and $13M in FL. It's run by Mitch McConnell's former chief of staff, Steven Law.

nodes.name: Fred Eychaner
nodes.abt: Fred Eychaner is the chairman of Newsweb Corporation, a media coonglomerate based in Chicago. He wsa the biggest democratic donor in the 2012 election cycle and donated $22.5M dollars between 2012 - 2016. $12M of that sum went to the Senate Majority PAC.

nodes.name: James Simons
nodes.abt: James Simons is a mathematician and billionaire hedge fund manager. He is known for his studies on pattern recognition. He is the founder of Renaissance Technologies, a private hedge fund firm based in New York City. According to the Center for Responsive Politics, Simons was ranked the #5 donor to federal candidates in the 2016 election cycle, coming behind co-CEO Robert Mercer, who is ranked #1 and donates to Republicans. Simons was the subject of a deep Dec 2017 profile in the New Yorker which revealed that he keeps a sizable part of his fortune in Bermuda in order to avoid paying taxes. He is married to Marilyn Simons, another prominent Democratic donor.

nodes.name: Alexander Soros
nodes.abt: Alexander Soros is the son of George and Susan Soros. He's the deputy chairman of the Open Society Foundation (the family philanthropic organization he administers with his other four siblings) and a PhD student at UC Berkeley.

nodes.name: Donald Sussman
nodes.abt: Donald Sussman is founder of Paloma Partners, a hedge fund company. He was Hillary Clinton's largest individual donor in 2016, having donated $22M dollars to superPACs supporting her election. He serves on Pro Publica's Board of Directors. Sussman gave $3M to Women Vote! and $3M to the Senate Majority PAC.

nodes.name: Greater NY Hospital Mgmt Corp
nodes.abt: The Greater NY Hospital Management Corporation is a self-described center for health care advocacy and expertise. This group donated $2Million dollars. to the Senate Majority PAC.

nodes.name: Henry Laufer
nodes.abt: Henry Laufer is an American mathematician and investor. He served as the Vice President of Research at Renaissance Technologies, the hedge fund company founded by James Simons. Laufer donated $6.4M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle, and his $2M donation to the Senate Majority PAC matches his other top contribution of $2M to Priorities USA.

nodes.name: Thomas Murphy
nodes.abt: Thomas Murphy is the chairman of Coastal Construction Group and the father of Florida's 2016 Democractic senate nominee, Patrick Murphy. In addition to contributing $2M to superPACs support his son's campaign, he was also a major contributor to the Senate Majority PAC.

nodes.name: Laurene Powell Jobs
nodes.abt: Laurene Powell Jobs is a venture capitalist, philanthropist and the widow of Apple founder Steve Jobs. She met her future husband while she was an MBA student at Stanford Graduate School of Business in 1990. Jobs' philanthropic interests primarily include education.  She donated $3.4M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle and her $1.5M gift to the Senate Majority PAC represents her largest investment of the cycle

nodes.name: George Soros
nodes.abt: George Soros is a Hungarian-American investor and business magnate. He moved to New York City in 1956 and founded Soros Fund Management in 1970. He went on to become one of the world's most successful investors. His political ideology is informed by his experience of fleeing Nazi-occupied Hungary when he was 13. He became active in American political campaigns after the election of George W. Bush. He gave $22.8M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle.

nodes.name: Senate Majority PAC
nodes.abt: Senate Majority PAC formed in 2011 "to make sure that our Democratic Senators and candidates would not be forced to face such overwhelming odds against them again." The group's "about" page cites the Citizen's United decision as being a catalyst for the six seats Democrats lost in 2010, suggesting that Democratic candidates were overwhelmed by advertising funded by conservative super PACs. They were the only liberal outside group to spend in all six of the most expensive senate contests of 2016.

nodes.name: Amalgamated Bank
nodes.abt: Founded on April 14, 1923, by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, Amalgamated Bank is the largest union-owned bank and one of the only unionized banks in the United States. Their services are often used by Democratic campaigns, including Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton's presidential campaigns. The bank extended nearly $26M dollars of credit to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee during the 15-16 election cycle.

nodes.name: Democratic National Committee
nodes.abt: The Democratic National Committee (DNC) is the formal governing body for the Democratic Party. It is responsible for coordinating strategy and supporting Democratic Party candidates at the local, state and national levels. It is also responsible for coordinating the presidential nominating convention for the party's nominee. The DNC filed $355M dollars in receipts for the 15-16 election cycle. They disbured $4.0M to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.

nodes.name: Actblue PAC
nodes.abt: ActBlue PAC bills itself as "the online clearinghouse for Democratic action." As a federally registered political action committee, it serves as a conduit for online contributions to Democratic candidates and committees. In the 15-16 election cycle ActBlue PAC registered over $205M dollars in contributions. It gifted $3.7M dollars to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.

nodes.name: Friends of Schumer
nodes.abt: Friends of Schumer is the principal campaign committee (PCC) of Charles Schumer, the Democratic senator from New York. He was re-elected in 2016 with 70% of the vote. The PCC registered $17.4M dollars of receipts with the FEC for the 15-16 election cycle, and allocated $3.0M to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.

nodes.name: People for Patty Murray
nodes.abt: People for Patty Murray is the principal campaign committee (PCC) of Patty Murray, the Democratic senator from Washington. She was re-elected in 2016 with 59% of the vote. The PCC registered $10.2M dollars of receipts with the FEC for the 15-16 election cycle, and allocated $1.3M to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.

nodes.name: Wyden for Senate
nodes.abt: Wyden for Senate is the principal campaign committee (PCC) of Ron Wyden, the Democratic senator from Oregon. He was re-elected in 2016 with 56% of the vote. The PCC registered $8.7M dollars of receipts with the FEC for the 15-16 election cycle, and allocated $1.0M to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.

nodes.name: Kaine for Virginia
nodes.abt: Kaine for Virginia is the principal campaign committee (PCC) of Tim Kaine, the Democratic senator from Virginia and the Vice Presidential nominee in 2016. Tim Kaine is running for re-election in 2018.  His PCC registered $4.0M dollars of receipts with the FEC for the 15-16 election cycle, and allocated $0.5M to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.

nodes.name: Schumer Committee for the Majority
nodes.abt: Schumer Committee for the Majority is a joint fundraising committee sponsored by Senator Charles Schumer of New York. It raised $2.6M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle and allocated $0.9M to the DSCC.

nodes.name: Feinstein for Senate
nodes.abt: Feinstein for Senate is the principal campaign committee (PCC) for Senator Diane Feinstein of California. Typically, PCCs raise the most money during the candidate's election year. Feinstein's election isn't until Nov 2018, but her PCC was still active in 2016 and raised a total of $593k dollars, allocating most of it to the DSCC.

nodes.name: Dem Senatorial Campaign Comm
nodes.abt: The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee (DSCC) is an organization which exists solely to elect Democrats to the United States Senate. The DSCC logged $180M dollars in receipts during the 15-16 election cycle and it allocated funds to all of the top six most expensive races.

nodes.name: Senate Leadership Fund
nodes.abt: This conservative superPAC spent directly in senate races and also donated to other superPACs such as Granite State Solutions--the most active outside spending force in the NH senate election.

nodes.name: Jay Faison
nodes.abt: Jay Faison is founder of ClearPath Foundation, a group which lobbies for "conservative" clean energy solutions. He co-wrote a New York Times op-ed with Republican Senator Lisa Murkowski in 2016 advocating for a reduction in regulations for hydropower permitting. Faison's June 2015 donation of $500k to Granite State Solutions was the first receipt processed by the superPAC. Faison gave $5.2M in entire election cycle. He lives in North Carolina.

nodes.name: James Davis
nodes.abt: James Davis is the owner and chairman of New Balance. Davis gave a total of $1.4M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle across 22 different conservative groups. He lives in Massachusetts.

nodes.name: Ray Barrette
nodes.abt: Ray Barrette was the chairman of White Mountain Insurance company which, despite its name, is based in Bermuda for tax reasons. Barrette gave over $270k dollars during the 15-16 election cycle across 13 different conservative groups. His largest gift was $50,000 to Granite State Solutions and he appears to be the largest donor to this group who actually lives in New Hampshire. Barrette stepped down from the company in November 2017.

nodes.name: Custom Mgmt Services
nodes.abt: Custom Mgmt Services Inc is a homeowners association management service. They donated $230k during the 15-16 cycle, including $50k to Granite State Solutions. It's unclear if they do business in New Hampshire, as their political donations were filed with a Sioux Falls, SD address and their website lists their address in Houston, TX.

nodes.name: Alamo PAC
nodes.abt: Alamo PAC is a political action committee based in Texas. They donated $605k during the 15-16 cycle across 48 different conservative groups. They gave $25k to Granite State Solutions on Sept 13, 2016.

nodes.name: William Duhamel
nodes.abt: William Duhamel is a founding manager of Route One Investments. He is also a member of the Stanford Center for Longevity's advisory council. Duhamel donated $375k across conservative and liberal groups. He gave $25k to Granite State Solutions. Duhamel lives in San Francisco, CA.

nodes.name: Thomas Kempner
nodes.abt: Kempner is the executive manager of Davidson Kempner Capital Management. He donated $335k dollars to conservative and liberal groups during the 15-16 cycle, including gifts to groups supporting Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump. Kempner gave $25k to Granite State Solutions in October 2016. He serves on the board of the Harvard Management Company (the group which manages Harvard's $36 billion dollar endowment). He lives in New York City.

nodes.name: Gregory Wendt
nodes.abt: Gregory Wendt is a portfolio manager at the Capital Group in San Francisco, CA. He donated $1.1m dollars during the 15-16 cycle across 44 conservative groups. He gave $25k to Granite State Solutions in October 2016.

nodes.name: Granite State Solutions
nodes.abt: This conservative superPAC existed solely to spend against Maggie Hassan (D) and in support of Kelly Ayotte (R) in NH. The group was lead by Brooks Kochvar--Kelly Ayotte's former campaign manager. Granite State Solutions spent $24.7M on the NH senate race (all of it between August 31 - October 28, 2016), with Sheldon Adelson and the Senate Leadership Fund providing 98% of the total.

nodes.name: Michael Bloomberg
nodes.abt: Michael Bloomberg is the former mayor of New York City and the founder of the Bloomberg media and software empire. He contributed $21m to his own superPAC, Independence USA PAC.

nodes.name: Independence USA PAC
nodes.abt: Independence USA is a one-man superPAC funded by Michael Bloomberg with the aim of "supporting candidates who show a willingness to participate in bi-partisan interactions on policy issues related to firearms, the environment, education, and marriage." During the 15-16 cycle, the superPAC spent $19.2M dollars and contributed the bulk of its funds in support of Pat Toomey (R-PA) and in opposition to Kelly Ayotte (R-NH).

nodes.name: Freedom Vote Inc
nodes.abt: Freedom Vote, Inc., is a 501(c)(4) outfit from Dayton, Ohio. Their tax-exempt status means they are not obligated to disclose their sources of financing to the FEC. According to an ethics complain filed by the CREW organization, the group violated the requirements of their 501(c)(4) status by spending more than half of their expenditures on political activity.

nodes.name: Peter Thiel
nodes.abt: Peter Thiel bio here

nodes.name: Robert Mercer
nodes.abt: Robert Mercer bio here

nodes.name: Linda McMahon
nodes.abt: Linda McMahon bio here.

nodes.name: Les Wexner
nodes.abt: Leslie Wexner bio here

nodes.name: Thomas McInerney
nodes.abt: Thomas E. McInerney bio here.

nodes.name: Haim Saban
nodes.abt: Haim Saban is an Israeli-American media magnate and investor. He's the founder of Saban Entertainment, a global television production company best known for their distribution of animated series such as Spider-Man and X-Men. Saban, a long-time supporter and donor of many pro-Jewish and Israel causes, has stated his main goal in multiple interviews: "I'm a one-issue guy, and my issue is Israel." Saban gave $9.8M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle and allocated $1.4M to the Senate Majority PAC.

nodes.name: Leahy for Senate
nodes.abt: Leahy for Senate is the principal campaign committee (PCC) of Patrick Leahy, the Democratic senator from Vermont. He was re-elected in 2016 with 60% of the vote. The PCC registered $3.9M dollars of receipts with the FEC for the 15-16 election cycle, and allocated $0.5M to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.

nodes.name: Chain Bridge Bank
nodes.abt: Chain Bridge Bank is a privately owned Washington DC-based bank which exists almost entirely in service to major Republican political campaigns. Similar to Amalgamated Bank (the employee-owned bank used by major liberal campaigns and groups), they offer services in a unique model which fits the start-up nature of political campaigns and super PACs. The bank was started by a former Republican senator (Peter Fitzgerald). When the 2008 John McCain campaign began having problems with Wachovia, the campaign transferred its accounts to Chain Bridge. Chain Bridge extended $15M dollars worth of credit to the National Republican Senatorial Campaign during the 15-16 election cycle.

nodes.name: Republican National Committee
nodes.abt: The RNC is a political committee that provides national leadership for the Republican Party. It is responsible for developing and promoting the Republican political platform, as well as coordinating fundraising, election strategy and nominating convention for each presidential race. The RNC is a "527" type of outside group which means, like super PACs, they can raise unlimited amounts of money from corporations, unions and donors. They transferred $8.5M dollars to the National Republican Senatorial Committee.

nodes.name: NRSC Targeted State Victory Fund
nodes.abt: The NRSC Targeted State Victory Fund is a Joint Fundraising Committee (JFC) between the NRSC and state-level Republican parties. The group was setup in response to the US Supreme Court McCutcheon vs FEC decision.  Before the 2014 McCutcheon v. FEC decision, the checks donors wrote to JFCs were subject to overall aggregate limits. Following the decision, those limits were removed, opening up the possibility of JFCs that involve many candidates or committees, which can then solicit one donor for a mega-contribution. Contributions to the NRSC Targeted State Victory Fund are funneled into state parties and the NRSC. The NRSC Targeted State Victory Fund supplied $2.1m dollars to the NRSC during the 15-16 election cycle.

nodes.name: Friends of John Thune
nodes.abt: Friends of John Thune is a Political Campaign Committee (PCC) attached to the campaign of John Thune, a Republican senator from South Dakota. It is one of the most prosperous PCCs and as of December 2017, its $11.3M dollars made it the third richest PCC behind Donald Trump and Elizabeth Warren (who is facing a 2018 re-election race). Thune was re-elected in 2016 and won't be running for re-election until 2022. The PCC gave $2M dollars to the NRSC during the 15-16 cycle.

nodes.name: Cornyn Majority Committee
nodes.abt: John Cornyn is a Republican senator from Texas and the former chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee. His joint fundraising PAC, the Corynyn Majority Committee, raised $2.2M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle and contributed $1.2M dollars to the NRSC.

nodes.name: Rubio Victory Committee
nodes.abt: Marco Rubio is a Republican senator from Florida and was a candidate for the Republican presidential nomination until dropping out of the race in the spring of 2016 and choosing to run for re-election to the Senate. His joint fundraising PAC, the Rubio Victory Committee, raised $4.7M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle and gave $754k dollars to the NRSC.

nodes.name: Blunt Victory Committee
nodes.abt: Roy Blunt is a Republican senator from Missouri who won re-election in 2016 --a close $79M dollar race against Democrat Jason Kander which represented the seventh most expensive senate race in 2016. His joint fundraising PAC, the Blunt Victory Committee, raised $2.3M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle and gave $545k dollars to the NRSC.

nodes.name: Isakson Victory Committee
nodes.abt: John Isakson is a Republican senator from Georgia. He won re-election for a 3rd term in 2016 with 55% of the vote, his lowest marigin of victory. The Isakson Victory Committee raised $692k dollars in the 15-16 election cycle and gave $518k dollars to the NRSC.

nodes.name: Charles Schwab
nodes.abt: Charles R. Schwab is the founder and former CEO of the Charles Schwab Corporation, a bank and brokerage firm. He is a major donor to the Republican National Committee's legal fund--an account which is being used to pay for expenses related to the Trump Russia investigation. Charles and his wife Helen donated $501k dollars to the NRSC.

nodes.name: Hatch Victory Committee
nodes.abt: Orrin Hatch is a Republican senator from Utah and has served in the senate since 1977, making him the longest serving Republican senator in Senate history. The Hatch Victory Committee gave $481k dollars to the NRSC in the 15-16 election cycle.

nodes.name: National Repub Senatorial Comm
nodes.abt: The National Republican Senatorial Committee (NRSC) is the conservative counterpart to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee (DSCC). The NRSC disbursed $133M dollars during the 15-16 cycle. It contributed to all ten of the top ten most expensive races in 2016, with its largest investment being made in Nevada ($7.4M dollars spent in opposition to Democrat Catherine Cortez Masto).

nodes.name: Freedom Partners Action Fund
nodes.abt: Freedom Partners Action Fund (FPAF) is a conservative superPAC launched by the Koch brothers at a 2014 presentation at the St. Regis Monarch Beach resort in Dana Point, California. The group is an affiliate of the Koch-funded 501c6 organization, Freedom Partners. The FPAF raised $28M dollars during the 15-16 election campaign, and the superPAC was a top source of conservative funds in three of the six most expensive senate races of 2016, with $10M dollars going to Ohio. This sum made them the highest spending outside group in the Ohio senate race. A large banner on their website states that their 2016 "efforts ensured pro-freedom control of the US senate.

nodes.name: Diane Hendricks
nodes.abt: Diane Hendricks is an American businesswoman and the widow of Ken Hendricks. She met her future husband in 1975 when she was selling custom-built homes and Ken was a roofing contractor.  Together, they started  ABC Supply--a major building supply company based in Wisconsin. Ken passed away in 2007 after falling through an under-construction sub-floor above his garage. Since then, Diane has become the richest female CEO in the country and has also started funding film productions such as "The Stoning of Soraya M." Diane donated $18M dollars during the 15-16 cycle, and gave $4M dollars to the Freedom Partners Action Fund.

nodes.name: Charles Koch
nodes.abt: Charles Koch is the chairman of Koch industries, a multinational conglomorate of manufacturing, refining and distribution of petroleum. According to Forbes magazine, Koch is the sixth richest person in the world. He is the founder of the Freedom Partners Action Fund superPAC and donated $3M dollars from his personal wealth, representing his largest on-record gift of the 15-16 election cycle.

nodes.name: Charles Koch 1997 Trust
nodes.abt: On October 15, 2014, Charles Koch seeded the newly created Freedom Partners Action Fund with $3M dollars from his "1997 Trust"--a reserve of money which yields no traceable search results except for campaign donations and its role in an FEC investigation opened in the summer of 2016, Matter Under Review (MUR) #7101. Other FPAF donations were also part of the MUR #7101 investigation. Ultimately, the investigation was dismissed in June of 2017 but documents regarding the investigation have not been made public.

nodes.name: Mountaire Corporation
nodes.abt: Mountaire Corporation is an agricultural food processing corporation based in Arksansas and the sixth largest poultry producer in the country. Its owner and chairman, Ken Cameron, is an active conservative donor who donated $9.7M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle, including $500k dollars to the Freedom Partners Action Fund from his own personal wealth, far less than the $3M dollars gifted by Mountaire Corporation.

nodes.name: Richard Gilliam
nodes.abt: Richard Gilliam is the founder of the Virginia-based coal extractor, Cumberland Resources. He was a top donor to Republican Governor Bob McDonnell's campaign in Virginia and was later appointed to an advisory position within McDonnel's administration. His $2M dollar donation to the Freedom Partners Action Fund represents the bulk of his $2.1m dollars spent during the 15-16 election cycle.

nodes.name: I360
nodes.abt: i360 is a for-profit data mining service funded by the Koch brothers. According to a Politico profile, "i360 links voter information with consumer data purchased from credit bureaus and other vendors. Information from social networks is blended in, along with any interaction the voter may have had with affiliated campaigns and advocacy groups." i360 was credited by Republican senator Cory Gardner for helping him unseat Democratic incumbent Mark Udall in his 2014 Colorado senate rate. i360 provided $1.6M dollars of receipts for the FPAF.

nodes.name: Wayne Laufer
nodes.abt: Wayne Laufer is the retired chief executive of Bois d'Arc, an energy company which was later purchased by Stone Energy. He donated $1.4M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle, with his $1.3M dollar donations to the Freedom Partners Action Fund representing the bulk of his allocation.

nodes.name: Paul Foster
nodes.abt: Paul Foster is the founder and chairman of Western Refining, a publicly traded crude oil refinery. In 2013, Texas governor Rick Perry appointed Foster to the University of Texas Board of Regents. In announcing the appointment, the Dallas Morning News highlighted Foster's role as a Perry donor, writing "Since 2000, Foster has donated more than $417,000 in campaign and in-kind contributions to Perry." Foster donated $3.7M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle, giving $1m to the Freedom Partners Action Fund and the rest going to 14 other conservative groups.

nodes.name: EMILY's List Women Vote!
nodes.abt: Women Vote! is a super PAC created by the () group, Emily's List. According to their official website, "EMILY’s List launched WOMEN VOTE! to harness the power of women voters to get more women elected. Since 1995, WOMEN VOTE! has been persuading and mobilizing women voters to get to the polls and vote for pro-choice Democratic women candidates." The superPAC raised $38M dollars in the 15-16 election cycle, and they spent $15.8M dollars in opposition to the four Republican candidates running against Democratic women in Nevada, New Hampshire, Pennsylvania and North Carolina.

nodes.name: Priorities USA
nodes.abt: Priorities USA is a liberal 501c4 social welfare organization. Due to their tax status, they are not required to disclose their donors and can accept gifts of unlimited amounts (though their super PAC, Priorities USA Action does disclose donations to the FEC). Priorities USA was the top donor to Women Vote, contributing $14.5M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle.

nodes.name: Emily's List
nodes.abt: EMILY's List is an American political action committee that aims to help elect pro-choice Democratic female candidates to office. It was founded by Ellen Malcolm (an IBM heiress) in 1985. The group's name is an acronym for "Early Money Is Like Yeast", Malcolm commenting that "it makes the dough rise." EMILY's List contributed $1.6M to Women Vote across five seperate transactions.

nodes.name: Majority Forward
nodes.abt: Majority Forward is a 501c4 social welfare organization created to support voter registration and voter turnout efforts. Due to their non-profit tax status, they are not required to disclose their donations to the FEC.  Majority Forward contributed $1.3M to Women Vote across five separate transactions.

nodes.name: Scott Shenker
nodes.abt: Scott Shenker is a computer scientist and professor at UC Berkeley. According to Google Scholar, he is one of the most cited computer science authors. He donated $1.4M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle, with his largest donation of  $1.2M dollars going to Women Vote.

nodes.name: Marilyn Simons
nodes.abt: Marilyn Simons is the president of the Simons Foundation and the wife of James Simons, a prominent Democratic donor.  Her philanthropic interests include funding science education in underserved communities. She donated $3.5M dollars during the 15-16 cycle, including $1m dollars donated to Women Vote.

nodes.name: Priorities USA Action + Emily's List Joint
nodes.abt: Priorities USA, Emily's List and Women Vote shared a joint fundraising committee (JFC) which allowed them to take in larger donations and disburse them to all three groups. These types of groups were setup in response to the US Supreme Court McCutcheon vs FEC decision.  Before the 2014 McCutcheon v. FEC decision, the checks donors wrote to JFCs were subject to overall aggregate limits. Following the decision, those limits were removed, opening up the possibility of JFCs that involve many candidates or committees, which can then solicit one donor for a mega-contribution. Donations to the JFC resulted in $0.9M being allocated to Women Vote.

nodes.name: Laure Woods
nodes.abt: A former clinical researcher in the pharmaceutical industry, Woods now devotes herself full-time to philanthropy. She’s president of the Laurel Foundation, which focuses on children’s health and education, and the Bay Area Lyme Foundation, which she cofounded after being diagnosed with the disease. She gave over $10M dollars during the 15-16 election and was one of the largest donors to groups supporting Hillary Clinton's candidacy. Woods gave .9M dollars to Women Vote.

nodes.name: AFT Solidarity
nodes.abt: AFT solidarity is a political 527 organization attached to the American Federation of Teachers (AFT) union, a large educator's union which has 1.7M members. They donated $875k dollars to Women Vote.

nodes.name: Pennsylvania
nodes.abt: The PA senate race ended up being the most expensive senate race in US history. Republican Pat Toomey defeated Democrat Kathleen McGinty by 100k votes (1.7% points)

nodes.name: New Hampshire
nodes.abt: The total cost of the NH senate race was $141M dollars, making it the second most expensive senate race of 2016 and of all time. Democrat Maggie Hassan defeated Republican incumbent Kelly Ayotte by 743 votes (0.1% points).

nodes.name: Nevada
nodes.abt: The total cost of the NV senate race was $127M dollars. Democrat Catherine Cortez Masto defeated Republican Joe Heck by 26k votes (2.4% points)

nodes.name: North Carolina
nodes.abt: The total cost of the NC senate race was $97M dollars. Republican Richard Burr defeated Democrat Deobrah Ross by 269k votes (5.8% points)

nodes.name: Ohio
nodes.abt: The total cost of the OH senate race was $90M. Republican Rob Portman defeated Democrat Ted Strickland by 1.1M votes (21.4% points).

nodes.name: Florida
nodes.abt: The total cost of the FL senate race was $91M dollars. Republican Marco Rubio defeated Democrat Patrick Murphy by 717k votes (7.7% points).

nodes.name: Amer Fed of SCM Employees (AFSCME)
nodes.abt: The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees is the largest trade union of public employees in the United States. It represents over 1.3M members and almost exclusively lends financial support to Democratic candidates.

nodes.name: Amer Fed of SCM Employees (AFSCME)
nodes.abt: The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees is the largest trade union of public employees in the United States. It represents over 1.3M members and almost exclusively lends financial support to Democratic candidates.

links.abt2: One Nation is a 501c4 social welfare organization operated by Karl Rove and his associates. Because they're tax exempt, they do not have to disclose their donors to the FEC. According to a leaked copy of their tax filings, the group spent about $40M in a largely successful push to protect the GOP's majority in the Senate, with over half of the $40M being provided by four anonymous donors.

Miriam Adelson (nee Ochsorn) is an Israeli doctor who specializes in treating addiction. She married Sheldon Adelson in 1991. In addition to funding conservative candidates, Miriam and Sheldon are major donors to Taglit-Birthright Israel and they also steer donations through their corporations, Sands Casino and the Adelson Drug Clinic.  Miriam and Sheldon gave matching $17.5M dollars to the Senate Leadership Fund.

Sheldon Adelson is a business magnate whose primary investments are hotels and casinos. He is the 19th richest person in the world and the largest individual donor from any party during the 2012 and 2016 election cycles. He gave $17.5M dollars to the Senate Leadership Fund.

Paul Singer is the founder of Elliott Management Corporation--a hedge fund which specializes in distressed debt acquisitions. Singer serves on the board of the Republican Jewish Coalition and has donated over $10M to conservative groups and candidates who support LGBT equality.
Petrodome Energy is a private oil and gas producer run by Ed Borsarge--a mathematician whose specialties include finance, medicine and energy. He wears a beret in most of his online photos.

Stephen Schwarzman is the CEO of The Blackstone Group, a global private equity firm. He made headlines in 2017 for his 70th birthday party costing $7M dollars. The party included a 12 minute fireworks show, roaming camels and a 'Happy Birthday' performance from Gwen Stefani.
Warren Stephens is the chairman, president and CEO of Stephens Inc, a privately held investment bank. He was an active donor in the 'Stop Trump' movement during the republican primaries.

Robert "Bob" McNair is a businessman best known for his ownership of the Houston Texans. He ignited controversy during the fall 2017 anthem-kneeling protests by comparing the player protests to 'inmates running the prison.' He apologized, and then retracted his apology in April 2018.

American Crossroads is a conservative super PAC that aims to focus its activities on what it sees as 'America's commitment to individual liberty, limited government, free enterprise and a strong national defense.' The organization was founded in 2010 by a group of Republican political operatives led by Karl Rove.

Kenneth Griffin is the CEO of the global investment firm, Citadel. During his sophomore year at Harvard (1987), he installed a satellite link to his dorm room in order to access real-time stock market data. He is an active art buyer, having paid millions for notable works of art by Paul Cezanne, Jackson Pollock and Jasper Johns.

Fred Eychaner is the chairman of Newsweb Corporation, a media coonglomerate based in Chicago. He wsa the biggest democratic donor in the 2012 election cycle and donated $22.5M dollars between 2012 - 2016.

James Simons is a mathematician and billionaire hedge fund manager. He is known for his studies on pattern recognition. He is the founder of Renaissance Technologies, a private hedge fund firm based in New York City. According to the Center for Responsive Politics, Simons was ranked the #5 donor to federal candidates in the 2016 election cycle, coming behind co-CEO Robert Mercer, who is ranked #1 and donates to Republicans. Simons was the subject of a deep Dec 2017 profile in the New Yorker which revealed that he keeps a sizable part of his fortune in Bermuda in order to avoid paying taxes. He is married to Marilyn Simons, another prominent Democratic donor.

Alexander Soros is the son of George and Susan Soros. He's the deputy chairman of the Open Society Foundation (the family philanthropic organization he administers with his other four siblings) and a PhD student at UC Berkeley.

Donald Sussman is founder of Paloma Partners, a hedge fund company. He was Hillary Clinton's largest individual donor in 2016, having donated $22M dollars to superPACs supporting her election. He serves on Pro Publica's Board of Directors. Sussman gave $3M to Women Vote! and $3M to the Senate Majority PAC.
The Greater NY Hospital Management Corporation is a self-described center for health care advocacy and expertise.

Henry Laufer is an American mathematician and investor. He served as the Vice President of Research at Renaissance Technologies, the hedge fund company founded by James Simons. Laufer donated $6.4M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle, and his $2M donation to the Senate Majority PAC matches his other top contribution of $2M to Priorities USA.

Thomas Murphy is the chairman of Coastal Construction Group and the father of Florida's 2016 Democractic senate nominee, Patrick Murphy. In addition to contributing $2M to superPACs support his son's campaign, he was also a major contributor to the Senate Majority PAC.

Laurene Powell Jobs is a venture capitalist, philanthropist and the widow of Apple founder Steve Jobs. She met her future husband while she was an MBA student at Stanford Graduate School of Business in 1990. Jobs' philanthropic interests primarily include education.  She donated $3.4M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle and her $1.5M gift to the Senate Majority PAC represents her largest investment of the cycle

George Soros is a Hungarian-American investor and business magnate. He moved to New York City in 1956 and founded Soros Fund Management in 1970. He went on to become one of the world's most successful investors. His political ideology is informed by his experience of fleeing Nazi-occupied Hungary when he was 13. He became active in American political campaigns after the election of George W. Bush. He gave $22.8M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle.

Founded on April 14, 1923, by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, Amalgamated Bank is the largest union-owned bank and one of very few unionized banks in the United States. Their services are often used by Democratic campaigns, including Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton's presidential campaigns. The bank extended nearly $26M dollars of credit to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee during the 15-16 election cycle which qualifies as an in kind contribution.

The Democratic National Committee (DNC) is the formal governing body for the Democratic Party. It is responsible for coordinating strategy and supporting Democratic Party candidates at the local, state and national levels. It is also responsible for coordinating the presidential nominating convention for the party's nominee. The DNC filed $355M dollars in receipts for the 15-16 election cycle. They disbured $4.0M to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.

ActBlue PAC bills itself as "the online clearinghouse for Democratic action." As a federally registered political action committee, it serves as a conduit for online contributions to Democratic candidates and committees. In the 15-16 election cycle ActBlue PAC registered over $205M dollars in contributions.

Friends of Schumer is the principal campaign committee (PCC) of Charles Schumer, the Democratic senator from New York. He was re-elected in 2016 with 70% of the vote. The PCC registered $17.4M dollars of receipts with the FEC for the 15-16 election cycle.

People for Patty Murray is the principal campaign committee (PCC) of Patty Murray, the Democratic senator from Washington. She was re-elected in 2016 with 59% of the vote. The PCC registered $10.2M dollars of receipts with the FEC for the 15-16 election cycle.

Wyden for Senate is the principal campaign committee (PCC) of Ron Wyden, the Democratic senator from Oregon. He was re-elected in 2016 with 56% of the vote. The PCC registered $8.7M dollars of receipts with the FEC for the 15-16 election cycle, and allocated $1.0M to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.

Kaine for Virginia is the principal campaign committee (PCC) of Tim Kaine, the Democratic senator from Virginia and the Vice Presidential nominee in 2016. Tim Kaine is running for re-election in 2018.  His PCC registered $4.0M dollars of receipts with the FEC for the 15-16 election cycle.
Schumer Committee for the Majority is a joint fundraising committee sponsored by Senator Charles Schumer of New York. It raised $2.6M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle.

Feinstein for Senate is the principal campaign committee (PCC) for Senator Diane Feinstein of California. Typically, PCCs raise the most money during the candidate's election year. Feinstein's election isn't until Nov 2018, but her PCC was still active in 2016 and raised a total of $593k dollars, allocating most of it to the DSCC.
This conservative superPAC spent directly in senate races and also donated to other superPACs such as Granite State Solutions--the most active outside spending force in the NH senate election.

Sheldon Adelson is a business magnate whose primary investments are hotels and casinos. He is the 19th richest person in the world and the largest individual donor from any party during the 2012 and 2016 election cycles.

Jay Faison is founder of ClearPath Foundation, a group which lobbies for "conservative" clean energy solutions. He co-wrote a New York Times op-ed with Republican Senator Lisa Murkowski in 2016 advocating for a reduction in regulations for hydropower permitting. Faison's June 2015 donation of $500k to Granite State Solutions was the first receipt processed by the superPAC. Faison gave $5.2M in entire election cycle. He lives in North Carolina.
James Davis is the owner and chairman of New Balance. Davis gave a total of $1.4M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle across 22 different conservative groups. He lives in Massachusetts.

Ray Barrette was the chairman of White Mountain Insurance company which, despite its name, is based in Bermuda for tax reasons. Barrette gave over $270k dollars during the 15-16 election cycle across 13 different conservative groups. His largest gift was $50k to Granite State Solutions and he appears to be the largest donor to this group who actually lives in New Hampshire. Barrette stepped down from the company in November 2017.

Custom Mgmt Services Inc is a homeowners association management service. They donated $230k during the 15-16 cycle, including $50k to Granite State Solutions. It's unclear if they do business in New Hampshire, as their political donations were filed with a Sioux Falls, SD address and their website lists their address in Houston, TX.

Alamo PAC is a political action committee based in Texas. They donated $605k during the 15-16 cycle across 48 different conservative groups. They gave $25k to Granite State Solutions on Sept 13, 2016.

William Duhamel is a founding manager of Route One Investments. He is also a member of the Stanford Center for Longevity's advisory council. Duhamel donated $375k across conservative and liberal groups.  Duhamel lives in San Francisco, CA.

Kempner is the executive manager of Davidson Kempner Capital Management. He donated $335k dollars to conservative and liberal groups during the 15-16 cycle, including gifts to groups supporting Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump. Kempner gave $25k to Granite State Solutions in October 2016. He serves on the board of the Harvard Management Company (the group which manages Harvard's $36 billion dollar endowment). He lives in New York City.
Gregory Wendt is a portfolio manager at the Capital Group in San Francisco, CA. He donated $1.1m dollars during the 15-16 cycle across 44 conservative groups.
Michael Bloomberg is the former mayor of New York City and the founder of the Bloomberg media and software empire. He contributed $21m to his own superPAC, Independence USA PAC.

Paul Singer is the founder of Elliott Management Corporation--a hedge fund which specializes in distressed debt acquisitions. Singer serves on the board of the Republican Jewish Coalition and has donated over $10M to conservative groups and candidates who support LGBT equality.

Freedom Vote, Inc., is a 501(c)(4) outfit from Dayton, Ohio. Their tax-exempt status means they are not obligated to disclose their sources of financing to the FEC. According to an ethics complain filed by the CREW organization, the group violated the requirements of their 501(c)(4) status by spending more than half of their expenditures on political activity.

Peter Thiel is a conservative entrepreneur. He is best known as one of the co-founders of PayPal and an early investor in Facebook. Thiel also financed a very public court battle between wrestler Hulk Hogan and Gawker media which resulted in Gawker's collapse. He was motivated to fund the court battle after Gawker publicly outed him in 2007 as being gay. Thiel gave $4.6M dollars to conservative groups during the 15-16 election cycle.

Robert Mercer is a computer scientist and the retired co-CEO of Renaissance Technologies, a hedge fund. He is also the primary investor behind Cambridge Analytics, the British political consulting firm whose aggressive data mining tactics have come under increased scrutiny both in the US and UK. The $500K dollars he donated to the Fighting for Ohio fund represents 2% of his 15-16 election cycle giving total ($24M)--all to conservative groups.

Linda McMahon is the co-founder of World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE), a media and entertainment company based in Connecticut. McMahon ran for senate in 2010 and 2012, losing both times. She was a prominent support of Donald Trump's candidacy and was later appointed as his Administrator of the Small Business Administration. The $0.4M dollars she gave to the Fighting for Ohio fund represents 3.6% of her total giving during the 15-16 election cycle ($11M dollars to conservative groups)

Kenneth Griffin is the CEO of the global investment firm, Citadel. During his sophomore year at Harvard (1987), he installed a satellite link to his dorm room in order to access real-time stock market data. He is an active art buyer, having paid millions for notable works of art by Paul Cezanne, Jackson Pollock and Jasper Johns. He gave $2.1M to the Senate Leadership Fund.

Leslie Wexner is the CEO of L Brands, a fashion retailer best known for Victoria's Secret and Abercrombie and Fitch. He is one of two top donors to the Fighting for Ohio fund who actually lives in Ohio. Wexner donated $1.2M dollars to conservative groups and candidates during the 15-16 election cycle

Mr. McInerney is the Chief Executive Officer and co-founder of Bluff Point Associates. Before founding Bluff Point Associates, Mr. McInerney served as a General Partner of the New York City-based private equity firm Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe since 1987, focusing on investments in the information/business services industry. He donated over $3M dollars to conservative groups during the 15-16 election cycle.

Richard Farmer is the chairman of the Cintas corporation, a company which provides uniforms and business supplies. The company was originally founded by Farmer's grandfather as a rag cleaning company. He is one of two top donors to the Fighting for Ohio fund who actually lives in Ohio. Farmer donated $580K during the 15-16 election cycle.

Howard Leach is a businessman and investor from California. He is also the former United States Ambassador to France, a post he held during the first George W. Bush administration. He acquired his wealth as the co-founder and president of multiple food processing corporations in California. He donated $624K dollars during the 15-16 election cycle.

Haim Saban is an Israeli-American media magnate and investor. He's the founder of Saban Entertainment, a global television production company best known for their distribution of animated series such as Spider-Man and X-Men. Saban, a long-time supporter and donor of many pro-Jewish and Israel causes, has stated his main goal in multiple interviews: "I'm a one-issue guy, and my issue is Israel." Saban gave $9.8M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle and allocated $1.4M to the Senate Majority PAC.

Leahy for Senate is the principal campaign committee (PCC) of Patrick Leahy, the Democratic senator from Vermont. He was re-elected in 2016 with 60% of the vote. The PCC registered $3.9M dollars of receipts with the FEC for the 15-16 election cycle.

Chain Bridge Bank is a privately owned Washington DC-based bank which exists almost entirely in service to major Republican political campaigns. Similar to Amalgamated Bank (the employee-owned bank used by major liberal campaigns and groups), they offer services in a unique model which fits start-up nature of political campaigns and super PACs. The bank was started by a former Republican senator (Peter Fitzgerald). When the 2008 John McCain campaign began having problems with Wachovia, the campaign transferred its accounts to Chain Bridge. Chain Bridge extended $15M dollars worth of credit to the National Republican Senatorial Campaign during the 15-16 election cycle which qualified as an in kind contribution.

The RNC is a political committee that provides national leadership for the Republican Party. It is responsible for developing and promoting the Republican political platform, as well as coordinating fundraising, election strategy and nominating convention for each presidential race.

The NRSC Targeted State Victory Fund is a Joint Fundraising Committee (JFC) between the NRSC and state-level Republican parties. The group was setup in response to the US Supreme Court McCutcheon vs FEC decision.  Before the 2014 McCutcheon v. FEC decision, the checks donors wrote to JFCs were subject to overall aggregate limits. Following the decision, those limits were removed, opening up the possibility of JFCs that involve many candidates or committees, which can then solicit one donor for a mega-contribution. Contributions to the NRSC Targeted State Victory Fund are funneled into state parties and the NRSC.

Friends of John Thune is a Political Campaign Committee (PCC) attached to the campaign of John Thune, a Republican senator from South Dakota. It is one of the most prosperous PCCs and as of December 2017, its $11.3M dollars made it the third richest PCC behind Donald Trump and Elizabeth Warren (who is facing a 2018 re-election race). Thune was re-elected in 2016 and won't be running for re-election until 2022. The PCC gave $2M dollars to the NRSC during the 15-16 cycle.

John Cornyn is a Republican senator from Texas and the former chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee. His joint fundraising PAC, the Corynyn Majority Committee, raised $2.2M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle.

Marco Rubio is a Republican senator from Florida and was a candidate for the Republican presidential nomination until dropping out of the race in the spring of 2016 and choosing to run for re-election to the Senate. His joint fundraising PAC, the Rubio Victory Committee, raised $4.7M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle.

Roy Blunt is a Republican senator from Missouri who won re-election in 2016 --a close $79M dollar race against Democrat Jason Kander which represented the seventh most expensive senate race in 2016. His joint fundraising PAC, the Blunt Victory Committee, raised $2.3M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle.

John Isakson is a Republican senator from Georgia. He won re-election for a 3rd term in 2016 with 55% of the vote, his lowest marigin of victory. The Isakson Victory Committee raised $692k dollars in the 15-16.

Charles R. Schwab is the founder and former CEO of the Charles Schwab Corporation, a bank and brokerage firm. He is a major donor to the Republican National Committee's legal fund--an account which is being used to pay for expenses related to the Trump Russia investigation. Charles and his wife Helen donated $501k dollars to the NRSC.

Orrin Hatch is a Republican senator from Utah and has served in the senate since 1977, making him the longest serving Republican senator in Senate history. The Hatch Victory Committee gave $481k dollars to the NRSC in the 15-16 election cycle.

Diane Hendricks is an American businesswoman and the widow of Ken Hendricks. She met her future husband in 1975 when she was selling custom-built homes and Ken was a roofing contractor.  Together, they started  ABC Supply--a major building supply company based in Wisconsin. Ken passed away in 2007 after falling through an under-construction sub-floor above his garage. Since then, Diane has become the richest female CEO in the country and has also started funding film productions such as "The Stoning of Soraya M." Diane donated $18M dollars during the 15-16 cycle.

Kenneth Griffin is the CEO of the global investment firm, Citadel. During his sophomore year at Harvard (1987), he installed a satellite link to his dorm room in order to access real-time stock market data. He is an active art buyer, having paid millions for notable works of art by Paul Cezanne, Jackson Pollock and Jasper Johns.

Charles Koch is the chairman of Koch industries, a multinational conglomorate of manufacturing, refining and distribution of petroleum. According to Forbes magazine, Koch is the sixth richest person in the world. He is the founder of the Freedom Partners Action Fund superPAC and donated $3M dollars from his personal wealth, representing his largest on-record gift of the 15-16 election cycle.

On October 15, 2014, Charles Koch seeded his newly created Freedom Partners Action Fund with $3M dollars from his "1997 Trust"--a reserve of money which yields no traceable search results except for campaign donations and its role in an FEC investigation opened in the summer of 2016, Matter Under Review (MUR) #7101. Other FPAF donations were also part of the MUR #7101 investigation. Ultimately, the investigation was dismissed in June of 2017 but documents regarding the investigation have not been made public.

Mountaire Corporation is an agricultural food processing corporation based in Arksansas and the sixth largest poultry producer in the country. Its owner and chairman, Ken Cameron, is an active conservative donor who donated $9.7M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle, including $500k dollars to the Freedom Partners Action Fund from his own personal wealth, far less than the $3M dollars gifted by Mountaire Corporation.

Richard Gilliam is the founder of the Virginia-based coal extractor, Cumberland Resources. He was a top donor to Republican Governor Bob McDonnell's campaign in Virginia and was later appointed to an advisory position within McDonnel's administration. His $2M dollar donation to the Freedom Partners Action Fund represents the bulk of his $2.1M dollars spent during the 15-16 election cycle.

i360 is a for-profit data mining service funded by the Koch brothers. According to a Politico profile, "i360 links voter information with consumer data purchased from credit bureaus and other vendors. Information from social networks is blended in, along with any interaction the voter may have had with affiliated campaigns and advocacy groups." i360 was credited by Republican senator Cory Gardner for helping him unseat Democratic incumbent Mark Udall in his 2014 Colorado senate rate.

Wayne Laufer is the retired chief executive of Bois d'Arc, an energy company which was later purchased by Stone Energy. He donated $1.4M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle, with his $1.3M dollar donations to the Freedom Partners Action Fund representing the bulk of his allocation.

Paul Foster is the founder and chairman of Western Refining, a publicly traded crude oil refinery. In 2013, Texas governor Rick Perry appointed Foster to the University of Texas Board of Regents. In announcing the appointment, the Dallas Morning News highlighted Foster's role as a Perry donor, writing "Since 2000, Foster has donated more than $417,000 in campaign and in-kind contributions to Perry." Foster donated $3.7M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle, giving $1M to the Freedom Partners Action Fund and the rest going to 14 other conservative groups.

Paul Singer is the founder of Elliott Management Corporation--a hedge fund which specializes in distressed debt acquisitions. Singer serves on the board of the Republican Jewish Coalition and has donated over $10 to conservative groups and candidates who support LGBT equality.

Priorities USA is a liberal 501c4 social welfare organization. Due to their tax status, they are not required to disclose their donors and can accept gifts of unlimited amounts (though their super PAC, Priorities USA Action does disclose donations to the FEC). Priorities USA was the top donor to Women Vote, contributing $14.5M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle.

Donald Sussman is founder of Paloma Partners, a hedge fund company. He was Hillary Clinton's largest individual donor in 2016, having donated $22M dollars to superPACs supporting her election. He serves on Pro Publica's Board of Directors. Sussman gave $3M to Women Vote! and $3M to the Senate Majority PAC.

EMILY's List is an American political action committee that aims to help elect pro-choice Democratic female candidates to office. It was founded by Ellen Malcolm (an IBM heiress) in 1985. The group's name is an acronym for "Early Money Is Like Yeast", Malcolm commenting that "it makes the dough rise." EMILY's List contributed $1.6M to Women Vote across five seperate transactions.

Majority Forward is a 501c4 social welfare organization created to support voter registration and voter turnout efforts. Due to their non-profit tax status, they are not required to disclose their donations to the FEC.

Scott Shenker is a computer scientist and professor at UC Berkeley. According to Google Scholar, he is one of the most cited computer science authors. He donated $1.4M dollars during the 15-16 election cycle, with his largest donation of  $1.2M dollars going to Women Vote.
Michael Bloomberg is the former mayor of New York City and the founder of the Bloomberg media and software empire. He contributed $21M to his own superPAC, Independence USA PAC.

Marilyn Simons is the president of the Simons Foundation and the wife of James Simons, a prominent Democratic donor.  Her philanthropic interests include funding science education in underserved communities. She donated $3.5M dollars during the 15-16 cycle, including $1M dollars donated to Women Vote.

Priorities USA, Emily's List and Women Vote shared a joint fundraising committee (JFC) which allowed them to take in larger donations and disburse them to all three groups. These types of groups were setup in response to the US Supreme Court McCutcheon vs FEC decision.  Before the 2014 McCutcheon v. FEC decision, the checks donors wrote to JFCs were subject to overall aggregate limits. Following the decision, those limits were removed, opening up the possibility of JFCs that involve many candidates or committees, which can then solicit one donor for a mega-contribution. Donations to the JFC resulted in $0.9M being allocated to Women Vote.

A former clinical researcher in the pharmaceutical industry, Woods now devotes herself full-time to philanthropy. She's the president of the Laurel Foundation, which focuses on children's health and education, and the Bay Area Lyme Foundation, which she cofounded after being diagnosed with the disease. She gave over $10M dollars during the 15-16 election and was one of the largest donors to groups supporting Hillary Clinton's candidacy.
AFT solidarity is a political 527 organization attached to the American Federation of Teachers (AFT) union, a large educator's union which has 1.7M members. They donated $875k dollars to Women Vote.

Senate Majority PAC formed in 2011 "to make sure that our Democratic Senators and candidates would not be forced to face such overwhelming odds against them again." The group's "about" page cites the Citizen's United decision as being a catalyst for the six seats Democrats lost in 2010, suggesting that Democratic candidates were overwhelmed by advertising funded by conservative super PACs. They were the only liberal outside group to spend in all six of the most expensive senate contests of 2016.

This conservative superPAC spent a total of $86 million dollars on 2016 senate elections, including $17M in NV, $15M in PA, $14M in NC and $13M in FL. It's run by Mitch McConnell's former chief of staff, Steven Law. $85M of their total $86M were spent on negative advertisement targeted at Democrats.

The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee (DSCC) is an organization which exists solely to elect Democrats to the United States Senate. The DSCC logged $180M dollars in receipts during the 15-16 election cycle and it allocated funds to all of the top six most expensive races.

The National Republican Senatorial Committee (NRSC) is the conservative counterpart to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee (DSCC). The NRSC disbursed $133M dollars during the 15-16 cycle. It contributed to all ten of the top ten most expensive races in 2016, with its largest investment being made in Nevada ($7.4M dollars spent in opposition to Democrat Catherine Cortez Masto).

Freedom Partners Action Fund (FPAF) is a conservative superPAC launched by the Koch brothers at a 2014 presentation at the St. Regis Monarch Beach resort in Dana Point, California. The group is an affiliate of the Koch-funded 501c6 organization, Freedom Partners. The FPAF raised $28M dollars during the 15-16 election campaign, and the superPAC was a top source of conservative funds in three of the six most expensive senate races of 2016, with $10M dollars going to Ohio. This sum made the the highest spending outside group in the Ohio senate race. A large banner on their website states that their 2016 "efforts ensured pro-freedom control of the US senate.

Independence USA is a private superPAC funded almost entirely by Michael Bloomberg with the aim of "supporting candidates who show a willingness to participate in bi-partisan interactions on policy issues related to firearms, the environment, education, and marriage." During the 15-16 cycle, the superPAC spent $19.2M dollars and contributed the bulk of its funds in support of Pat Toomey (R-PA) and in opposition to Kelly Ayotte (R-NH).

Women Vote! is a super PAC created by the political action committee, Emily's List. According to their official website, 'EMILY's List launched WOMEN VOTE! to harness the power of women voters to get more women elected. Since 1995, WOMEN VOTE! has been persuading and mobilizing women voters to get to the polls and vote for pro-choice Democratic women candidates.' The superPAC raised $38M dollars in the 15-16 election cycle, and they spent $15.8M dollars in opposition to the four Republican candidates running against Democratic women in Nevada, New Hampshire, Pennsylvania and North Carolina.

Senate Majority PAC formed in 2011 "to make sure that our Democratic Senators and candidates would not be forced to face such overwhelming odds against them again." The group's "about" page cites the Citizen's United decision as being a catalyst for the six seats Democrats lost in 2010, suggesting that Democratic candidates were overwhelmed by advertising funded by conservative super PACs. They were the only liberal outside group to spend in all six of the most expensive senate contests of 2016.

The National Republican Senatorial Committee (NRSC) is the conservative counterpart to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee (DSCC). The NRSC disbursed $133M dollars during the 15-16 cycle. It contributed to all ten of the top ten most expensive races in 2016, with its largest investment being made in Nevada ($7.4M dollars spent in opposition to Democrat Catherine Cortez Masto).

The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee (DSCC) is an organization which exists solely to elect Democrats to the United States Senate. The DSCC logged $180M dollars in receipts during the 15-16 election cycle and it allocated funds to all of the top six most expensive races.

This conservative superPAC existed solely to spend against Maggie Hassan (D) and in support of Kelly Ayotte (R) in NH. The group was lead by Brooks Kochvar--Kelly Ayotte's former campaign manager. Granite State Solutions spent $24.7M on the NH senate race (all of it in a two month binge between August 31 - October 28, 2016), with Sheldon Adelson and the Senate Leadership Fund providing 98% of the total.

Independence USA is a one-man superPAC funded by Michael Bloomberg with the aim of "supporting candidates who show a willingness to participate in bi-partisan interactions on policy issues related to firearms, the environment, education, and marriage." During the 15-16 cycle, the superPAC spent $19.2M dollars and contributed the bulk of its funds in support of Pat Toomey (R-PA) and in opposition to Kelly Ayotte (R-NH).

Women Vote! is a super PAC created by the political action committee, Emily's List. According to their official website, "EMILY's List launched WOMEN VOTE! to harness the power of women voters to get more women elected. Since 1995, WOMEN VOTE! has been persuading and mobilizing women voters to get to the polls and vote for pro-choice Democratic women candidates." The superPAC raised $38M dollars in the 15-16 election cycle, and they spent $15.8M dollars in opposition to the four Republican candidates running against Democratic women in Nevada, New Hampshire, Pennsylvania and North Carolina.

Fighting for Ohio is a Super PAC supporting the campaign of Sen. Rob Portman (R-OH). It was started by Barry Bennett, a Republican consultant and former adviser to Portman. The group spent heavily on negative advertisement targeting the Democratic candidate, former Ohio Governor Ted Strickland.

Senate Majority PAC formed in 2011 "to make sure that our Democratic Senators and candidates would not be forced to face such overwhelming odds against them again." The group's "about" page cites the Citizen's United decision as being a catalyst for the six seats Democrats lost in 2010, suggesting that Democratic candidates were overwhelmed by advertising funded by conservative super PACs. They were the only liberal outside group to spend in all six of the most expensive senate contests of 2016.

This conservative superPAC spent a total of $86 million dollars on 2016 senate elections, including $17M in NV, $15M in PA, $14M in NC and $13M in FL. It's run by Mitch McConnell's former chief of staff, Steven Law. $85M of their total $86M were spent on negative advertisement targeted at Democrats.

The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee (DSCC) is an organization which exists solely to elect Democrats to the United States Senate. The DSCC logged $180M dollars in receipts during the 15-16 election cycle and it allocated funds to all of the top six most expensive races.

The National Republican Senatorial Committee (NRSC) is the conservative counterpart to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee (DSCC). The NRSC disbursed $133M dollars during the 15-16 cycle. It contributed to all ten of the top ten most expensive races in 2016, with its largest investment being made in Nevada ($7.4M dollars spent in opposition to Democrat Catherine Cortez Masto).

Freedom Partners Action Fund (FPAF) is a conservative superPAC launched by the Koch brothers at a 2014 presentation at the St. Regis Monarch Beach resort in Dana Point, California. The group is an affiliate of the Koch-funded 501c6 organization, Freedom Partners. The FPAF raised $28M dollars during the 15-16 election campaign, and the superPAC was a top source of conservative funds in three of the six most expensive senate races of 2016, with $10M dollars going to Ohio. This sum made the the highest spending outside group in the Ohio senate race. A large banner on their website states that their 2016 "efforts ensured pro-freedom control of the US senate.

Women Vote! is a super PAC created by the political action committee, Emily's List. According to their official website, "EMILY's List launched WOMEN VOTE! to harness the power of women voters to get more women elected. Since 1995, WOMEN VOTE! has been persuading and mobilizing women voters to get to the polls and vote for pro-choice Democratic women candidates." The superPAC raised $38M dollars in the 15-16 election cycle, and they spent $15.8M dollars in opposition to the four Republican candidates running against Democratic women in Nevada, New Hampshire, Pennsylvania and North Carolina.

Senate Majority PAC formed in 2011 "to make sure that our Democratic Senators and candidates would not be forced to face such overwhelming odds against them again." The group's "about" page cites the Citizen's United decision as being a catalyst for the six seats Democrats lost in 2010, suggesting that Democratic candidates were overwhelmed by advertising funded by conservative super PACs. They were the only liberal outside group to spend in all six of the most expensive senate contests of 2016.

This conservative superPAC spent a total of $86 million dollars on 2016 senate elections, including $17M in NV, $15M in PA, $14M in NC and $13M in FL. It's run by Mitch McConnell's former chief of staff, Steven Law. $85M of their total $86M were spent on negative advertisement targeted at Democrats.

The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee (DSCC) is an organization which exists solely to elect Democrats to the United States Senate. The DSCC logged $180M dollars in receipts during the 15-16 election cycle and it allocated funds to all of the top six most expensive races.

Women Vote! is a super PAC created by the political action committee EMILY's List. According to their official website, "EMILY's List launched WOMEN VOTE! to harness the power of women voters to get more women elected. Since 1995, WOMEN VOTE! has been persuading and mobilizing women voters to get to the polls and vote for pro-choice Democratic women candidates." The superPAC raised $38M dollars in the 15-16 election cycle, and they spent $15.8M dollars in opposition to the four Republican candidates running against Democratic women in Nevada, New Hampshire, Pennsylvania and North Carolina.

The National Republican Senatorial Committee (NRSC) is the conservative counterpart to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee (DSCC). The NRSC disbursed $133M dollars during the 15-16 cycle. It contributed to all ten of the top ten most expensive races in 2016, with its largest investment being made in Nevada ($7.4M dollars spent in opposition to Democrat Catherine Cortez Masto).

Senate Majority PAC formed in 2011 "to make sure that our Democratic Senators and candidates would not be forced to face such overwhelming odds against them again." The group's "about" page cites the Citizen's United decision as being a catalyst for the six seats Democrats lost in 2010, suggesting that Democratic candidates were overwhelmed by advertising funded by conservative super PACs. They were the only liberal outside group to spend in all six of the most expensive senate contests of 2016.

It contributed to all ten of the top ten most expensive races in 2016, with its largest investment being made in Nevada ($7.4M dollars spent in opposition to Democrat Catherine Cortez Masto).

Freedom Partners Action Fund (FPAF) is a conservative superPAC launched by the Koch brothers at a 2014 presentation at the St. Regis Monarch Beach resort in Dana Point, California. The group is an affiliate of the Koch-funded 501c6 organization, Freedom Partners. The FPAF raised $28M dollars during the 15-16 election campaign, and the superPAC was a top source of conservative funds in three of the six most expensive senate races of 2016, with $10M dollars going to Ohio. This sum made the the highest spending outside group in the Ohio senate race. A large banner on their website states that their 2016 "efforts ensured pro-freedom control of the US senate.

The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees is the largest trade union of public employees in the United States. It represents over 1.3M members and almost exclusively lends financial support to Democratic candidates. They contributed to all six races.
